author: Tom B.

description:
Good burritos, really friendly staff, nice location. ++++

Only issues is that they don't steam tortillas, which I think is pretty important for a good super burrito (keeps it stretchy). This is a very minor point though, overall, really like this place.
author: Avi W.

description: Cheap food, tacos are full of meat, quick service.  Only negative for some might be that the place looks a little run down, but that's part of the charm
author: John M.

description: Heavenly salsa verde, super cheap and yum
author: Ann L.

description:
Excellent burrito
close to union square. 
I got the super burrito with avocado. 
They were very nice and let me taste the fresh horchata and watermelon juice.  Both very tasty. 
I would go here again
author: Jeffrey F.

description:
It had such potential, I mean there was avocado for God's sake! 

I could ALMOST overlook the big pieces of pork fat in the carnitas super burrito - no, not really, not at all, no I can't. The salsa verde was watery and flavorless, the rice was soaked in grease from the carnitas...which basically leaves...the tortilla. 
Ya..that's right..the tortilla was perfectly fine.
author: Candy C.

description: Not good! We had a bit stomache pain after. We thought in San Fransisco even the worst Burrito place is way better than the best one in Germany. Best Burrito we ever had is still Dolores in Berlin.
author: Hun T.

description: Awesome burrito! Huge and delicious, definitely recommend for those looking for more of a local place then the tourist fare around union square!
author: Matt L.

description: Great call for a quick bite.  Super fast service, very tasty food.  We had the regular and super tacos, would recommend the super tacos.  Had the pastor, chicken with green sauce and chorizo.  They were all god but think that the chicken was the best.
author: David F.

description: I love it that a decent mexican place is so close to the financial district and is cheap and good. I've had lunch here several times. After spending an evening at Mikkeller with a friend, I hoped to have an after-drink meal here, looked the place up on Yelp, only to find it "closed". Well, that was according to the Yelp hours but walking by the place we discovered that it was open after all. Oh the elation! I've never been disappointed eating here and i look forward to my next opportunity to eat at a gold nugget of a place in the midst of over-priced financial district faire. They have all the extra features you want in a burrito place. Salsa bar, with jalapenos and radishes. Free chips. Mexican drinks (horchata, etc.) and futbol on the TV. Not to mention friendly service.
author: Rich M.

description:
Ok. I never review places on Yelp. But this place deserves all of the stars in the city. Cheap, quick, fresh, made-to-order tacos, burritos, nachos. Clean atmosphere, authentic feel. 

Oftentimes places that are empty are empty for a (not so great) reason. This place is empty because people don't know about it, I think. Very much a hidden gem. I will certainly seek it out the next time I'm in SF. Delicious.
author: Danielle R.

description: I ordered a pastor super burrito and it was just ok... Lacked flavor and I found myself not wanting to finish it...
author: Samantha W.

description:
Since that awesome place on 6th closed and was replaced by a fancy pants burger place, you are pretty limited in your choices for real Mexi in this part of the city.  This fits the bill, from the obnoxiously loud Tejano blasting, to the strange fresco poorly depicting a gaucho and peasant girl dancing, to the stale chips that are strangely addicting.

I prefer the tacos to the burritos here as burrito lacked any sort of real distinguishing flavor. The tacos came with double the meat of your average mission taqueria, and were delicious. 
A solid option.
author: Jonny C.

description: Being from SoCali I'm pretty picky when it comes to Mexican food. This is my new favorite in SF. The salsa verde alone is worth the trip and the Lengua taco was juicy and fresh. Will be back for sure.
author: Jodi Lynn S.

description: I've walked passed this place so many times, finally stopped by to try the tacos. Delicious and very filling tacos, as well as flautas (taquitos if you ask me). Friendly workers, clean establishment, and complimentary chips with salsa (my fav green salsa). Everything was on point, not too fussy or ghetto. Definitely the new go-to spot for hole in the wall Mexican food.
author: Annette S.

description: A well kept secret! Almost hard to find, sort of a sketchy street... but probably the best taqueria walking distance from the mall. They have different tortillas, pinto and refried beans... free self serve water, everything comes with chips and salsa.. and very inexpensive, especially for the area. This place beats Cancun (the other nearby taqueria) because there is more seating, better cuts of meat and they ask you what you want as they are cooking in. Also the staff is actually pleasant.
author: Tim V.

description: This is the only place in the neighborhood to get decently priced food that isn't packaged for tourists.  The food tastes like every other taqueria in SF, but that's definitely superior to the Union Sq/ Westfield crap that we find elsewhere.
author: Matthew D.

description:
Pollo asado super burrito
No rice, no sour cream
Pinto beans
No pico de gallo
Orange hot sauce
Avocado
Onions and cilantro

BOMB! One of the best burritos in SF.
On a good day the chicken has an almost confit texture. Crunchy and rendered.
Orange sauce is a secret but it really makes all the difference in the world.
Love that they really grill the tortilla so it's a bit flaky and gooey. They go nuts with the cheese.

If you go no rice, I suggest going no pico, otherwise it gets a bit watery.
author: Anthony B.

description: Decent Mexican food that is reasonably priced, especially for the area. The chips were weak sauce store-bought, but I can live with that. It was nice to be able to feed myself and my two kids for less than $25 in SF.
author: Stoph M.

description:
4.5 stars for a solid vegetarian burrito.

The cook isn't shy about filling the burrito well, so it was refreshing not to constantly ask him to add more lettuce or beans as is necessary at other places. Portion sizes were quite big and excellent for the price, which was quite low considering that the restaurant is located near the touristy Union Square area. Ate the burrito at 6 pm and it kept me full for the rest of the night, which is commendable.

The chips and salsas are a bit lacking, so docked half a star for that. It was nice of them to let me know that the green salsa that they put in burritos (not the green salsa that is packaged with the chips) had pork in it. Service was minimal but I'm fine with minimal service if the food is good.
author: Rutvij B.

description: I was so excited to try this place bc of reviews but I was very disappointed. Ordered a carne asada burrito, which ended up to be a tasteless, rice burrito. 75 percent is the burrito was rice, 20 percent fillers, and 5 percent meat... Huge let down.... Chips and salsa were good though.
author: Ian K.

description:
The burritos are definitely appropriately large for being made this close to the mission.  And they have a decent selection of more authentic flavors (lengua, pork stomach, cabeza) but the flavor was just not all there.  But, if you're hungry and don't want to go to some nasty chain or pay through the nose this place is a great spot for hungry wanderers stuck in the Tenderloin.  And the price is right for the portion size.  And the staff is really nice.  Of course, it is in the Tenderloin so that's either good for people watchers or bad for the flinchy.  Your call.
We had carne asada and pastor super burritos and everyone but the 6 year old finished theirs with gusto.  And the leftovers made a welcome breakfast for my girls the next day.
author: P H.

description:
Rarely does a place get better and better every time you eat there, but Taqueria Castillo is the exception to the rule. 

My review is only for the tacos. I usually get the Pastor/Carnitas super taco which runs about $2.50 or $3. Unlike most other places, the meat is really juicy and tender and the vegetables - onion, tomato, avocado - are all very fresh. I think their tacos could compete with almost any taco I've had in the Mission and is even better than some - Pancho Villa, for example. 

Even though I'm not a big fan of the blinding florescent lighting or the  cafeteria style decor, the friendliness of the staff and the quality of food more than make up for any faults. This place is a true TL gem - far better than any other Mexican place in the area (and I've tried nearly every one).
author: Car C.

description: Being from the east coast, I admittedly don't have the best handle on what makes for a great burrito, but the Super Burrito here was all that and more. This is a great no-frills place with excellent food and good prices.
author: Mike P.

description: Everything we tried was amazing!! Anything from the burritos to the shrimp cocktail to the shrimp with steak! It was not only delicious but also very reasonably priced! Everyone was very accommodating!
author: Stephanie A.

description: Oh my goodness the pork super taco with a side of refried beans! Amazing! The food is cheap but sooooo delicious.
author: Caroline W.

description:
I love this place.  In fact, I joined yelp just so I could review it.  The food is tasty, the prices are reasonable, the staff is always friendly, and they give you free chips and salsa.  For a quick, cheap lunch, this place is unbeatable.

(Also, it's veggie friendly: they make a simple vegan burrito that always hits the spot.)
author: Zachary L.

description:
Who likes big burritos?! Who likes avocado?! Who likes lots of meat?! *that's what she said* I DO I DO! Taqueria Castillo is my go to place for burritos in the whole city. Alright alright, it's in a seedy part of downtown. But what hidden food treasure in San Francisco isn't?  Good food is when I'd risk my life to eat.  And people wonder why I'm chubby...but I digress. 

The guys that work here are super nice. They don't speak much English and I don't speak much Spanish, but we still communicate and have our laughs. There's only two of them so prepare to wait a bit during lunch hours.  

They're agua frescas are delicious.  They have a random fruit one and horchata at all times. And now to the important part, THE BURRITOS.  The best thing about this place is that they give you avocado in their super burritos. It makes so much difference. You take a bite into the burrito that gets some of the rice, MEAT, onions and cilantro, salsa, and then a cool ultra yummy piece of avocado.  No beans for me.  I always ask to nix those. They grill the meat on the spot for you so it's nice and hot in the burrito.  Super fresh!  

So if you're downtown and you want a real burrito, get your booty to Taqueria Castillo. Oh yeah, and say hi to the crackheads for me on the way there.
author: Lisa X.

description: I was skeptical or rather terrified to visit this place, because of the location. It is located in the lower part of the Tenderloin District, not pretty!  But, the food is great! Fresh and large portions with every order. My coworkers also love it, they call it burrito in the hood! Give it a try, if you are in the hood.
author: Hum V.

description: I rarely care enough to write a review unless something really really sucks. This place does.  If this were the only choice for Mexican food in  SF, I would buy a ticket to ANYWHERE in Mexico to satisfy that craving. Go to the mission, Castro or even chipotle. There's good Mexican eats in SF to be sure. But not here. Plus it's really filthy. AYOR.
author: Patrick S.

description: Visiting from L.A. And felt like a burrito. By far the best I've ever had. Good thing I had cash because they don't take credit card.
author: Raul F.

description:
You're all scaredy cats haha.. Bad area? This is on the very border between the big retail stores of downtown/Union Square and the Tenderloin and 6th street area. Nothing's gonna happen to you from when you walk that little half block from Powell station to this place haha. Plus the front of the Payless and those stairs to Powell station used to be way more crowded with people you all would probably consider "shady characters".. when really most of them are just hanging out and smoking weed.. which you would know if you opened your ears when you walked by them.

Anyway.... This is a good place. Good food, good prices. Plus they give very generous portions, even on a regular taco which is probably one of the cheapest things you can get. I almost always left extremely full after just 2 tacos and some chips. Also, this is one of the last spots left with free chips, and you can take as many little trays as you want, no charge for extra.

One of the people who cooks has a look on his face like he's tired of his job, but he's not rude or anything, and I know that feeling, so I don't blame him. Plus his food is great, and your food is ready fast, even when it's busy in there... And he cooks by himself, so what can you say... Everyone else has a very friendly attitude and the service is great. I left them a tip every time because they deserved it. Their customer service definitely outshines any other taqueria in the city. I don't expect any taqueria to be extremely friendly or anything, usually you just get cold stares and not much talking, which doesn't bother me because I'm used to it, but these people are friendly without being overly friendly and fake.
author: Steve R.

description: If your looking for authentic Mexican, this is the spot! They have bomb aguas too. Cash only but still 5 stars.
author: Jorge C.

description:
Matt has an infrequent day-off and wifey had a short working day before the Fourth of July holiday. Matt picked her up to have lunch together and waiting for the kids to get off from school so we can enjoy the pleasure of the holiday eve together. "The warm weather is so nice in recent weeks, why not?"

We wanted to eat at one of Matt's bookmarked places, unfortunately and not surprising many of the places were crowded for lunch as well as no parking spot available to us. Matt should've drove his company car, because he can park anywhere in the city, damn!

We landed at this hole in the wall Taqueria in the heart of the Tenderloin. (Ghetto, huh?) There was nobody dining here at the midday meal. Matt ordered the Carnitas (Grilled-Pork) Super-Burrito. The $6.75 Super silver-bullet had the usual condiments, you'll find on the popular taqueria item. The meat was cooked very well and not too burnt. 

Wife had a Grilled Steak Quesadilla Suiza. The simple dish is just 2 thinly sliced meat smothered in melted Mexican cheese and sandwiched in a grilled flour tortilla. What is really annoying is that she has the tendency to play with her food. The cheese was so gooey, that she used the cheese as an imaginary jump-rope. "Does somebody have a bib?"

The only disapproval is that the restaurant's beverage cooler doesn't work appropriately. Wife wanted a nice iced cold Corona Beer, but instead got a soda as well. Our canned soda was lukewarm, and we had to ask for a cup of ice for our soda. Other than the questionable drinks, our meal was a solid 3-stars.
author: Matt G.

description:
This is a great place to for a burrito fix.  

Honestly I had low expectations when I first walked in to this quiet fluorescent lit restaurant.  But having had a disappointing super burrito from a FiDi taco truck, I decided to come here in the hopes that ANYTHING would be better than what I had previously.

So I had the carne asada burrito with black beans and everything on it, in hopes of it being acceptable (again, still thinking about that taco truck).  And then, just like in a commercial, someone suddenly put money into the jukebox which then begun to play loud and cheerful Spanish music.  It was at that moment that I took a bite of my burrito in slow motion..... I was so surprised and delighted to find that it was delicious!!

The restaurant doesn't have a salsa bar, but it had something just as good.  They had the same to-go cups for salsa and pico de gallo, only at this restaurant, they were already packaged for you! No more making messes at the salsa bar, just grab and go.  How considerate.

And right next to them were napkins in a dispenser.  Yes I always expect to be given just one flimsy napkin and seeing napkins free for the taking never ceases to amaze me!

Taqueria Castillo is tasty and convenient! I'll have to pass by this area more often.
author: Erica D.

description: Delicious food, affordable...free unlimited chips and salsa with every meal, and last but not least just a very sweet welcoming and caring staff. Stumbled upon here when I was craving a burrito in the city and so glad I found it.
author: Carolina A.

description: This place was really good and close to everything in union square. I ordered this huge burrito and the chicken was cooked perfectly and they also give you free chips, salsa and water. They also aren't expensive and the size was great.
author: Madison W.

description:
Service: You'd expect, by the rough surroundings, the workers here to be jaded and dull.  But no, they're very friendly and helpful.  They joke around a lot and are quick to chat, which gives the place a nice laid back atmosphere.

Price: Most entrees are under $10 and the fixings and chips are free, very reasonable.

Food: They don't hold back on the flavor or the quantity.  Like avocados?  They'll cut open a fresh juicy one and slice it up on your dish.  Like salsa?  They got three delicious and unique options, from tangy to spicy to refreshing.
author: Mack D.

description:
It's taken over a year, but I've finally figured out how to order a Burrito I like in San Francisco. Thought I didn't like this place, but just realized I don't like what San Francisco calls a burrito.

Quailty and flavor of the meat here isn't the best you'll find, but everything else is top notch. I recommend the chorizo.
author: Mark F.

description: Great food,great service,the carne asada super burrito with black beans and avocado was just what I wanted. No complaints at all best mexican food I've had in awhile.
author: Sean L.

description: It's just a simple Mexican joint, but that's basically all you need. Quick, authentic, and friendly. My "regular chicken" burrito was huge and tasty. If you're in the area and need a bite, this is the place to go.
author: Makiko O.

description: Good food! I have been to Taqueria Castillo twice. Both times I got a chicken burrito and it hit the spot! They make it fresh and it really reflects in the taste. The second time I got 2 carne asada tacos as well and they were piled high with meat! The price is extremely reasonable and the food is great!  I will be back!
author: Heather S.

description:
Open on a busy downtown street.  Camera pans out and it's Market Street on a Friday.  It's early so the tourists are still scarce, rubbing the sleep from their eyes.  The hookers are just finishing their shift and their eyes are clouded with sleepiness.  It's the part of Market that tourists, theaters go-ers and opera go-ers have to get past in order to reach their cultured destination.  

Zoom in on Christina, dressed in her usual dumpy, shapeless shift and carrying her bright pink bag.  She is wearing tennis shoes and jeans.  Her BF drops her off on one of the sketchy parts of Market.  He is totally unaware of the peril that he has brought upon Christina.

Heeh.  My life in movies.  I was going to go to Macy's to buy some suits on this particular Friday and got a ride downtown with the BF.  To me, downtown is more 5th and Market.  For the BF, it was around 10th and market.  Men are from Mars, Women are more sensible.  

I hadn't had breakfast yet and I couldn't shop/snatch/wrestle for clothing without a snack.  After all, I hate shopping as much as men hate getting their chest waxed.  But I was willing to do it once a year.  And Macy's was having a sale.  Walking along Market towards the booming capitalistic glow of commerce, I saw this sign for some mexican food behind that awful urban clothing store that opened up on the corner from farmerbrowns.  

Nothing makes me happier than a burrito in the morning.  But on this day, I settled on a quesadilla.  I was disappointed that it was not very cheap.  I was disappointed that it was not very tasty.  It did not make my scalp tingle or my heartstrings soar in any way.  It made me stop eating it about half way through.
author: Christina C.

description: Decent food for the price. Employees were friendly. The place itself was nothing special, only a handful of tables to sit at...I am assuming they do a lot of takeout.
author: Rachel P.

description: Excellent shrimp burrito! Great flavor, plenty of shrimp. Fast service. Couldn't be happier.
author: Erin B.

description: I used to work in this area,  dicey area to hang out in,  but a  great place to pick up a burrito.     Good prices,   Ghetto neighborhood though....   Steak Burrito's are the bomb!   There Salsa is Great too!
author: Jerry P.

description:
I came here some time ago.Despite the location I have passed by here and have seen people in here.I thought another place to get/or try some decent Mexican food out.This was the day..after passing the hollering man near the Powell Station I ventured over to Taqueria Castillo. 

Upon entry I noticed a few tables and fridge with cold drinks they had on display to the left I believe.You walk toward the back and order.The menu is above and the food selection is right in front of you.Yes,you can watch them make the food. 

So,I had thought what do I feel like: burrito or nachos.Chicken or beef fillings.Well,I did decide on getting a veggie burrito.I haven't done that in quite awhile.Wow,the taste was good,fresh and tasty.I can't say how good it was again and this being my first veggie burrito in quite sometime.It has been a LONG TIME.My burrito was filled with whole beans,cheese,rice,lettuce,sour cream and nice thick slices of beautiful avocado.I had other little precious things in there,but the avocado slices sealed the deal.I enjoyed the burrito very much and I can't comment on the other menu options.The place was little quiet,but the workers were nice and quick with my order. 

Chips,meh..but I would come back here for the veggie burrito. 

No hot sauce pls and prices decent.
author: Dani D.

description: The friendliest girls in the city.  The Alambre (Fajitas with cheese and bacon) is unreal
author: Jesse K.

description:
Looking for a quality "mission" burrito but can't make it to the Mission? I found myself in this situation, jetlagged and starving here for a conference at Moscone from NYC. I didn't think such a place existed near all these malls and big box stores but I'm glad I saw their 4 star review on Yelp. 

I agree with all the reviews saying that this place is friendly, fresh and tasty. A tad more expensive than I expected but worth it. The place is in a rather large space, echoing with Mexican folk songs and families enjoying good grub. It saved me.
author: Jin J.

description:
Average taqueria food at average downtown prices in one of the scummiest corners around, one block and a lifetime in the wrong direction from the tourist hotels.  Breakfast and lunch only.  There's a juke box with 100% Mexican music.  It's cavernous and a little run down.  From inside you can look at the construction and destruction and destitution, catch a wifi signal from somewhere, and feel relatively safe and insulated.

They also have a bunch of colorful original landscape paintings and an ambitious wall mural by the same artist, and a couple Diego Rivera posters, love here amidst the chaos.
author: Gil S.

description:
This place was great. It's right on the border of Tenderloin, so if roaming through the heart of dicey neighbourhoods isn't for you, you're less than a half block from safety. I'm happy to say that I did not witness any sketchy behaviour during my visit. 

Anyway, we came for a late lunch and ordered fresh horchata, fresh melon juice, two Mexican Cokes (can't get these in Canada), two huge dinner platters, and a fish taco, plus complimentary chips and salsa, the tab was only $24. This would be a $50 meal in my native Toronto. 

The green chile enchilada platter was delicious, and while I found my tamales a bit dry, I was able to remedy that with some fresh, spicy, chunky salsa. The fish taco was lovely as well, loaded with chunks of avocado and onion. Did I mention astronomical portions? No? Okay, the portions are astronomical. I'm a big eater and we had a busy day of walking uphill planned and I was good until late at night. 

The staff is extremely friendly and authentic, offering up samples without prompting.
author: Steve J.

description: My go-to place once a week. Not the best locale (on the western cusp of downtown), but such is life in San Francisco. The fare is quite good and consistent; and service is efficient. $2.75 gets me a fresh, loaded vegetarian taco; an unbeatable value for a healthy and delicious lunch. Really glad to have them as neighbors.
author: R R.

description: This place makes the best carne asada burritos! The server is always really nice and makes the burrito exactly the way you want it. As soon as you pick your meat, he lays out the tortilla on the grill, sprinkles cheese over it and grills the meat before throwing it on top of the melted cheese. He even cuts fresh slices of avocado into your burrito! I've never had a bad burrito here. The meat is very tasty and not too salty like some other places I've been to. There is abundant seating which is always a plus! I definitely recommend this place for a quick meal!
author: Danielle W.

description: Super nice staff!!!! The burrito is huge and made fresh in front of you. I also really enjoy the fact that they pre-boxed all the salsa already even though it made me look like a hoarder, grabbing like a million boxes of salsa verde. Definitely coming back
author: Dorian T.

description: Cooked my carne asada fresh as I got there...mmm tasty
author: Mario W.

description: Super friendly staff, giant burritos, sliced avocado, convenient (but not so convenient it's crowded) location, fresh ingredients, quick service.  Can't ask for anything more!
author: Kate J.

description: wonderful experience with tacos de pescados. really yummy!!! @@@
author: Paolo D.

description: Yum! I work around the corner from this place and eat here frequently. I love the quesadilla Castillito...smaller than a burrito but still pretty filling. Great staff and even better food!
author: Gerry B.

description:
hmm 

Paying just over 5 dollars for 2 tacos at taqueria castillo vs. paying just over 3$ for 2 tacos at taqueria mana's 1.50 mini tacos...taqueria castillo is alot closer to my workplace plus gives out free chips and salsa. 

Winner = Taqueria Castillo

hmm

Paying five bucks for a huge breakfast burrito vs. 8 bucks for a faux breakfast burrito at Amoura's inside the bloomingdale's across from my workplace.

Winner = Taqueria Castillo

I'll return!
author: Mike A.

description:
This place is the straight up JAM.  I've been coming here for years and just can't get enough.  Whether it's huevos con chorizo, burritos, ultra-mega stylee quesadilla or a carne asada plate - the folks at Castillo Mason are always on point.

The ingredients are always fresh, the food is prepared right in front of you to your liking, huge portions and best of all it's CHEAP!  Super good bang for your buck.  The hombres making your burritos are artists.  They move so fast even Bruce Lee (R.I.P.) would be jealous.   Serious skill on da grill.

If you wanna get a serious and delicious grind on without the hit to the pocketbook, step inside Castillo and get busy!!!

*note - doesn't seem like they have weekend/evening hours.  Hit up the McAllister Street location.  Same great food/prices and people.
author: J. V.

description: Coming from Austin, TX, I have some pretty high expectations for Mexican food. I was kind of worried coming to California that I wouldn't be able to find anything that satisfies my desire for good Mexican food, but this place definitely exceeded what I could hope for. The quesadilla castillito is particularly good, if not mis-named. It's much more like a burrito in that it's burrito shaped and cheese isn't the main ingredient.
author: Seth H.

description: Excellent every time. Great price, especially for the area. When I go to union square, I usually eat here to avoid tourists and over priced food.  The people are friendly, too.  I love the super burritos and the super nachos (enough food for two people, easily).
author: Anthony D.

description: I work in this neighborhood and most of the food options within short walking distance are in the mall across the street, which is actually kind of horrible.  There are good spots deeper into the Tenderloin, for sure, but for something quick around the corner, it's slim pickins.  I came across this taqueria once while debating which of the 6 different Indian restaurants on the corner of Turk and Eddy I should frequent...and went that direction instead.  And it's solid - I've had the veggie tacos, a veggie burrito, and quesadilla at different times and they're all tasty and pretty cheap.  The block is, indeed, a little grim and the restaurant is no-frills, but it's a good, dependable option that allows me to avoid eating Sbarro or some other skanky mall food.  As someone who tends to load up on the salsa verde, I appreciate the unlimited salsa to-go.
author: Stacey M.

description: This was probably the biggest burrito I have ever had. I couldn't believe the amount of chicken he threw down, after two scoops, I was like, OK, is that it? Nope, one more scoop. Walking back to the office, I actually think I sprained by shoulder the weight was so intense. And when I got it home tonight and reheated for a post-gym, pre-Mighty meal, it was delicious. The size of this thing is worth the trip alone, making this above average burrito a perfect five stars.
author: Jason B.

description: I just got back from eating lunch here and I am so impressed. I ate a BBQ pork torta and it was to die for. I of coarse added a little refried on it, I always suggest this on a torta. They have fresh carrot juice  but it was a little expensive. I have not found many great taquerias in SF, mainly because I hate venturing into the emo infested mission. The area is definitely off the beaten track if you work in the Financial District but it is well worth it.
author: Bryan M.

description: Great find. I ordered the super taco with al pastor and spicy salsa. It was fantastic. They melt the cheese to the tortilla which is a really nice touch. The al pastor was really good, much like El Castillito on Church St. (Hum, I wonder if they are related.) They aren't the giant more than you can eat at once tacos, and 1 won't be a meal for most people. However, for $3.10 out the door, it was satisfying. The neighborhood isn't that bad. It's just off a quite section of Market, but only a block from the Po
author: V M.

description: Carne Asada torta is all I have to say. Best taqueria in downtown area period, and I've looked. Burritos are massive and satisfying. Meat is cooked on the spot and ingredients are fresh. East Bay taquerias are the best but on this side, this place can hang with them. Ghetto neighborhood so go during lunch time where there is daylight. Good selection of Jarritos too!
author: Erik W.

description:
For those of you lamenting its closing, report of its death have been greatly exaggerated.

I think this place is technically "Taqueria Castillo B" on Mason. It's a little gem on an uninspired and skanky stretch of Mason Street. This place has become "the" local cheap burrito shop for my office. 

The veggie burrito is my measure of all taquerias, and I'm damn happy with what my little smiling man behind the counter works up for me. He's not stingy with his avocado, either.

We are moving soon, and this is one of the few things I will miss about the slime pit of humanity that 5th and Market. Anyone have a comparable outfit near 2nd and Mission?!
author: Bouncy D.

description: oh yes. what a find! i've been working nearby for years! and why did i not discover this place earlier? Burritos are yummm and the quesadillas are the same size as the burritos!  totally satisfies the burrito fix when i don't want to take the trek to Pancho Vila.
author: Anna B.

description: just plain average. authentic seeming, but very "fast food" -like. vegi options few.
author: Jade P.
